greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of n-digit lunar primes.
comment: Although a(1) through a(6) are divisible by 9, a(7) is not.
link: D. Applegate, C program for lunar arithmetic and number theory

D. Applegate, M. LeBrun and N. J. A. Sloane, Dismal Arithmetic, arxiv:1107.1130 [math.NT], July 2011. [Note: we have now changed the name from "dismal arithmetic" to "lunar arithmetic" - the old name was too depressing]
D. Applegate, M. LeBrun, N. J. A. Sloane, Dismal Arithmetic, J. Int. Seq. 14 (2011) # 11.9.8.
Index entries for sequences related to dismal (or lunar) arithmetic
program: (PARI) A87636=[]; A087636(n)={while(#A87636<n,A87636=concat(A87636,0)); !A87636[n] && A87636[n]=sum(k=10^(n-1),10^n-1,is_A087097(k)); A87636[n]} \\ Store results in array A87636 to avoid re-calculation. - _M. F. Hasler_, Nov 15 2018
xref: Cf. A087062 (lunar product), A087097 (lunar primes), A087638 (partial sums).
results.author: Marc LeBrun and _N. J. A. Sloane_, Oct 26 2003
